bibl.title: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Michael E. Connor, July 28, 1928

div1.p: [Carter] asks Connor to confirm citations of publications that he has authored in order to verify these references for Henry Rose Carter's manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Michael E. Connor, July 28, 1928
div1.opener:
Bibliographic
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
July 28, 1928.
Dear Doctor Connor:
div1.p:
All of you old friends of Father and myself are much in my
heart and thoughts, but, since his death, save when acutely ill, I
have put all of my time on getting his MSS in such shape, as he would
have wished it, for publication. For this reason I have not even tried
to tell you of what I felt about your beautiful tributes to Father--but
then what I felt was beyond words anyway and I knew that you understood.

“At long last ” the most important most of the references in Father's
bibliography are being verified: In this connection, however, I should
be very grateful if you could help me out by telling me the exact place
(periodical or book)
in which I can find the following (referred to in Section 1, Epidemiology
of Father's History of Yellow Fever):
P.10:“Connor, M. E. (1922)Reports presence of aegypti in Mexico City.
P.16:Connor, M. E. (1923):Critical number of aegypti may be different
for residence district of natives of endemic
centers from that of hotels and lodging house
P.34:Connor, M. E. (I. H. B.)(1923 or 1924)? Had case (or cases) of pneumo
nia presented to him in summer or fall of 192[unclear]
as yellow fever In Mexico City)? on account of bloody sput
P.17:Connor, M. E. and Caldwell,------------- (what are his initials?) (19[unclear]
Regional focus in district of Papaloapan River. calling
it (probably quoting Guiteras) “hacienda endemicity”)

Also are any of the above, save the last mentioned, written with a
co-author?

I should be very much your debtor for the above information and than
to have it at your earliest convenience as it is an important part of the
bibliography.

With all manner of good wishes to you and your, in which I know Mrs.
Gorgas would join did she know I was writing.
